review.title: Is Intelligence Artificial?
review.abstract: Our understanding of intelligence is primarily directed at the level of human beings. This paper will attempt to give a more unifying definition that can be applied to everything that we know of. The definition would be used more to verify intelligence, where a scale would also be required to measure how much. A version of an accepted result of AI is then put forward as the acid test for Artificial Intelligence itself. Recent work has been more from a direction of mechanical processes, where this paper will not try to refute the idea of intelligence, but only to put it in a more general context.
histories: This new version adds some clarity to the discussion, which has realised a new idea. Also the opportunity to extend or update some sections. Some new references
This new version adds some clarity to the discussion, which has realised a new idea. Also the opportunity to extend or update some sections. Some new references

metadata.title: DCS Paper

sections.text: This essay tries to give a more consistent definition that can be applied to everything we know, the definition would be used more to verify intelligence, with a scale needed to measure how much. A version of an accepted result of artificial intelligence is then presented as a litmus test for the artificial intelligence itself. Recent work tends to focus on mechanical processes, and this essay will not attempt to refute the idea of intelligence, but only to put it in a more general context. Keywords: artificial intelligence, intelligence, definition, model.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This paper will try to give a more consistent definition that can be applied to everything we know. In writing a paper recently [3], it became clear that there is no proper or concise definition of what artificial intelligence is. Since this is really just an extension of intelligence, it also means that it is difficult to define intelligence, even if it is hard coded. A few examples of definitions of intelligence are as follows: The ability to apply knowledge and skills to be considered intelligent in a computer program. It is able to make the decision on what to do next.

sections.heading: 2 A Universal Intelligence
sections.text: This year, it is only a matter of time before an agreement is reached.

sections.heading: 3 Human-Level Artificial Intelligence
sections.text: The ability of a machine to artificially imitate intelligent human behavior. (Merriam Webster) (1) Artificial intelligence is the study of human intelligence so that it can be artificially replicated. (2) Artificial intelligence is the study of human intelligence and artificially replicated actions so that the resulting rationality exhibits a reasonable level of rationality. (3) What is rationality? - > "Doing the Right Thing." (WikiBooks, AI Definition) The characteristic of a machine that is able to learn reason through which it can normally learn functions associated with human intelligence. (McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific & Technical Terms) These definitions refer to human intelligence and act like creativity that cannot be easily programmed.

sections.heading: 3.1 An Acid Test for Human-Level Artificial Intelligence
sections.text: If a self-confident or conscious program can be written, intelligence will result from the correct development of the model. Inherent in this is the ability of the program to learn, because if it is to be self-aware of new information, it must be able to understand the new model first. Many movies and programs have shown that the artificial intelligence program overlays it, which is necessary for a higher level of intelligence: Proposition 3: It can be said that a company has a higher level of (artificial) intelligence when it correctly and consistently overlays its environment. Any over-regulation would have to be correct and probably consistent to remove the possibility of a random act. This would also imply that the program was aware of what it was doing. If we are defined by our model, then it would be more obvious that higher intelligence is capable of breaking the coding of the model, but that is not so clear.

sections.heading: 4 One Related Work Example
sections.text: The argument of Section 3.1 is the kind of argument also given by Searle [7] with his "Chinese Space" example: a person who has no knowledge of Chinese can provide answers to Chinese questions by associating symbols that he / she understands with the Chinese, and then with rules supplied to manipulate them. He also points out that intention and causal elements (neurons, synapses, nervous system, etc.) are missing as keys in human intelligence and the difficulty of artificially creating them. These elements seem to be missing from the process that man uses to answer Chinese space questions that are defined at a higher level and are the kind of process that a computer would have to use. The argument is that following the symbolic process does not lead to a human understanding, but only to repeating the algorithm and therefore a computer program would not be able to understand it.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: It is as if it is an attempt to change the system. It is as if it is a system that is able to surpass itself. It is as if it is a system that overcomes itself. It is as if it is. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system. It is as if it is a system.

An Old Question Reformulated, Minds & Machines, Vol. 20, pp. 203-212, DOI 10.1007 / s11023-010-9193-z. [5] McCarthy, J. (1979).

referenceMentions.context: When writing a paper recently [3], it became clear that there is no neat or concise definition of what Artificial Intelligence is.
This is the domain of the Physicists (for example, [1][6]) who have the more difficult task of a unifying theory for the whole Universe.
This is the domain of the Physicists (for example, [1][6]) who have the more difficult task of a unifying theory for the whole Universe.

1 is the sort of argument also given by Searle [7] with his ‘Chinese room’ example: A person with no knowledge of Chinese, can give replies to Chinese questions, by associating symbols that he/she does understand with the Chinese ones and then also using supplied sets of rules to manipulate them.
This also relates to the computer program or algorithm [4] that would be used to teach the computer and there are differences between a static set of rules and a dynamic system that can change.

Searle also quotes McCarthy [5] as stating: ‘Machines as simple as thermostats can be said to have beliefs, and having beliefs seems to be a characteristic of most machines capable of problem solving performance.
Are we mainly running on automatic ourselves? We are supposed to have a ‘selfish gene’ [2], but that is more for self-preservation than selfish acts.

Recent work has been more from a direction of mechanical processes, where this paper will not try to refute the idea of intelligence, but only to put it in a more general context.
